fields.value: More Than Just a Pretty Face? Dataset

dsDescriptionValue.value: This study explores the use of Twitter and Instagram by fashion models and the extent to which social media use is empowering for these individuals. The dataset consists of tweets, Instagram posts and photographs of eight different models; a content analysis was carried out on this information. Building off of Erving Goffman's work on Gender Advertisements, the prevalence of visually subordinating cues such as the feminine touch, relative size, aversion, and the ritualization of subordination was examined. The thesis for this project is: Female fashion models' social media profiles are a careful blend of agency and constraint.

publicationCitation.value: More Than Just a Pretty Face? Female Models' Management of Identity on Twitter and Instagram

value: The Twitter and Instagram profiles for Rosie Tapner, Keke Lindgard, Ajak Deng, Ashley Smith, Hanne Gaby Odiele, Hannah Holman,  Charlotte Di Calypso, and Jessica White were sampled.

fields.value: "New York Magazine ""Model Manual"": http://nymag.com/fashion/models/  Rosie Tapner Twitter: https://twitter.com/Rosie_Tapner Rosie Tapner Instagram: http://instagram.com/rosietapner  Keke Lindgard Twitter: https://twitter.com/Kekelindgard Keke Lindgard Instagram: http://instagram.com/kekelindgard  Ajak Deng Twitter: https://twitter.com/AJAK_DENG Ajak Deng Instagram: http://instagram.com/ajak_deng  Ashley Smith Twitter: https://twitter.com/gappylady Ashley Smith Instagram: http://instagram.com/asherfats  Hanne Gaby Odiele Twitter: https://twitter.com/hannegabysays Hanne Gaby Odiele Instagram: http://instagram.com/hannegabysees  Hannah Holman Twitter: https://twitter.com/hannahhol Hannah Holman Instagram: http://instagram.com/hannahutah  Charlotte Di Calypso Twitter: https://twitter.com/CdiCalypso Charlotte Di Calypso Instagram: http://instagram.com/chadicalypso  Jessica White Twitter: https://twitter.com/IamJessWhite Jessica White Instagram: http://instagram.com/iamjesswhite"

"For my research I used a qualitative approach, doing content analysis of eight female fashion models' Twitter and Instagram accounts.   The final sample was arrived at through a random and purposive sampling of the New York Magazine ""Model Manual."" This ""Model Manual"" contains an initial listing of 850 models (this number includes both men and women. The only criteria necessary to be on the list is being a working model). This initial listing was first narrowed down to include only females. The sample of 718 female models was then further narrowed to include only models that had both Twitter and Instagram accounts.   The 275 models who were active on both Twitter and Instagram were divided into their ""Model Manual"" categories of ""Newcomer,"" ""Rising Star,"" ""Established,"" and ""No Classification"" (this final category being created by the researcher). These lists were then narrowed down via a random sampling using a computer generated ""random"" number. Ultimately two models were chos
en from each category.   For each model approximately 40 tweets and 30 Instagram posts were chosen for coding. All of the data precedes November 5th, 2013.
